Comment: Triggered by the user pressing a button that says something like "Discuss the information with the app" while the user is looking at p1's data
Print: Which time period would you like to look at?
Ok, let's look at week 1 to week 8 then. You need to XXXXX

Comment: Case1: User selects any period across the first 8 weeks, where there has been a steady increase in temperature difference.
Print: We can see that the temperature difference between {{p1name}}'s healthy foot and {{p1name}}'s foot ulcer increased. This means it's likely that {{p1name}}'s foot ulcer has been getting worse. Would you like us to look together at the data more closely and see if we can understand why {{p1name}}'s foot ulcer has been getting worse?

Comment: If Yes, then
Print: Let's look at the data that shows how often {{p1name}} wears {{p1posspronoun}} boot when {{p1pronoun}} is at home, when {{p1pronoun}} is at work and when {{p1pronoun}} is out. You need to XXXXX
We can see that during this time period {{p1name}} often didn’t wear {{p1posspronoun}} boot while {{p1pronoun}} was at home.
Now look at the data that shows how many of steps {{p1name}} takes in different locations (home, at work, or when {{p1pronoun}} is out). You need to XXXXX

We can see that {{p1name}} takes around {{p1u1stepsHome}} steps a week while {{p1pronoun}} is at home. Because {{p1name}} wasn't wearing {{p1posspronoun}} boot much at home, this means that {{p1pronoun}} wasn't wearing {{p1posspronoun}} boot for many of the steps {{p1pronoun}} took.

In total {{p1name}} only wore {{p1posspronoun}} boot for {{p1u1stepsPercTotal}}% of the steps {{p1pronoun}} took. It's likely that {{p1name}'s foot ulcer has got worse because {{p1pronoun}} hasn't been wearing {{p1posspronoun}} boot as much as {{p1pronoun}} should.

For the best chance of a good recovery, {{p1name}} should wear {{p1posspronoun}} boot all the time {{p1pronoun}} is active. This means {{p1name}} needs to wear it when {{p1pronoun}} is at home as well as when {{p1pronoun}} goes out.
Thanks for talking with me. I hope this has been helpful. Bye!

Comment: Case4: User selects any period that crosses the boundary of week 8 and 9, where the temperature difference switches from increasing to decreasing.
Print: Ok, let's look at week 7 to week 10 then. You need to XXXXX

We can see that in weeks 7 and 8, the temperature difference between {{p1name}}'s healthy foot and {{p1name}}'s foot ulcer increased. This means it's likely that {{p1name}}'s foot ulcer has been getting worse. But in weeks 9 and 10, the temperature difference between {{p1name}}'s healthy foot and {{p1name}}'s foot ulcer decreased. This means it's likely that {{p1name}}'s foot ulcer has been getting better. Would you like us to look together at the data more closely and see if we can understand why {{p1name}}'s foot ulcer has been getting better?

Comment: If Yes, then
Print: Let's look at the data that shows how often {{p1name}} wears {{p1posspronoun}} boot when {{p1pronoun}} is at home, when {{p1pronoun}} is at work and when {{p1pronoun}} is out. You need to XXXXX
We can see that up in weeks 7 and 8, {{p1name}} usually didn't wear {{p1pronoun}} boot at home, even though he took around {{p1u4stepsHome}} steps a week at home.

In total {{p1name}} only wore {{p1posspronoun}} boot for {{p1u4stepsPercTotalA}}% of the steps {{p1pronoun}} took. It's likely that {{p1name}'s foot ulcer has got worse because {{p1pronoun}} hasn't been wearing {{p1posspronoun}} boot as much as {{p1pronoun}} should.
There was a change at the end of week 8 and {{p1name}} started wearing {{p1posspronoun}} boot more often while {{p1pronoun}} was at home.

In weeks 9 and 10, {{p1name}} wore {{p1posspronoun}} boot for {{p1u4stepsPercTotalB}}% of the steps {{p1pronoun}} took.  It's likely that {{p1name}'s foot ulcer started to improve because {{p1pronoun}} started wearing {{p1posspronoun}} boot more.

For the best chance of a good recovery, {{p1name}} should wear {{p1posspronoun}} boot all the time {{p1pronoun}} is active. This means {{p1name}} needs to wear it when {{p1pronoun}} is at home as well as when {{p1pronoun}} goes out.
Thanks for talking with me. I hope this has been helpful.

Comment: Triggered by the user pressing a button that says something like "Discuss the information with the app" while the user is looking at p2's data
Print: Which time period would you like to look at?

Comment: Case1: User selects any period across the first 8 weeks, where there has been a modest decrease in temperature difference.
Print: The temperature difference decreased somewhat over this period. This indicates that your foot ulcer was getting a bit better. Would you like us to look together at the data more closely and see if see if we can identify anything you were doing that could have contributed to this improvement?

Comment: If Yes, then
Print: Look at the data that shows how often you wear your boot when you’re at home, when you’re at work and when you’re out. We can see that during this time period you always wore your boot while you were out of the house and that you spent {{stepsPerc}}% of your waking hours out of the house.
In total you were wearing your boot for {{stepsPerc}}% of the steps you took over this period, and this is why we started to see an improvement.
For the best chance of a good recovery, you should wear your boot all the time you are active.

Comment: If No, then
Print: Why not?

Comment: If Because I’m busy, then
Print: Ok, I’ll ask you again later. Bye!

Comment: If Because it’s boring, then
Print: It will only take a minute or two and it might help your foot ulcer to get better. It’s important that you understand how your behaviour can impact on your recovery. Are you sure we can’t spend a few minutes looking at this together?

Comment: If Ok, then
Print: Look at the data that shows how often you wear your boot when you’re at home, when you’re at work and when you’re out. We can see that during this time period you always wore your boot while you were out of the house and that you spent {{hoursPerc}}% of your waking hours out of the house.
In total you were wearing your boot for {{stepsPerc}}% of the steps you took over this period, and this is why we started to see an improvement.
For the best chance of a good recovery, you should wear your boot all the time you are active.

Comment: If No I don’t want to, then
Print: Ok, you know where I am if you need me.

Comment: Case2: User selects any period across the last 4 weeks, where there has been quite a sharp increase in temperature difference.
Print: The temperature difference increased over this period. This indicates that your foot ulcer was deteriorating. Would you like us to look together at the data more closely and see if there are any possible causes of this deterioration?

Comment: If Yes, then
Print: Look at the data that shows how often you wear your boot when you’re at home, when you’re at work and when you’re out. We can see that during this time period you spent a lot of time at home --- you spent {{timeHomePerc}}% of your time at home.

We can also see that you weren’t wearing your boot as much as you should while you’re at home. During this time period you only wore your boot for {{stepsPerc}}% of the steps you took while you were at home.

This means that over this time period you were only wearing your boot for {{stepsPerc}}% of the steps you took, which is likely to have contributed to the deterioration of your foot ulcer over this period.
For the best chance of a good recovery, you should wear your boot all the time you are active. This means you need to wear it when you’re at home as well as when you go out.

Comment: Case3: User selects any period that crosses the boundary of week 8 and 9, where the temperature difference switches from decreasing to increasing.
Print: Up until the end of week 8, the temperature difference was decreasing, which indicates that your foot ulcer was getting better. But since the end of week 8, the temperature difference has been increasing, which indicates your foot ulcer has been deteriorating. Would you like us to look together at the data more closely and see if we can identify anything you have been doing differently that could have contributed to this change?

Comment: If Yes, then
Print: Look at the data that shows how often you wear your boot when you’re at home, when you’re at work and when you’re out. We can see that up until the end of week 8 you always wore your boot while you were out of the house and that you spent {{timeHomePerc}}% of your waking hours out of the house.
In total you were wearing your boot for {{stepsPerc}}% of the steps you took over this period, and this is why we started to see an improvement.
After week 8, you started to spend much more time at home. --- you spent {{timeHomePerc}}% of your time at home.
We can also see that you weren’t wearing your boot as much as you should while you’re at home. During this time period you only wore your boot for {{}}% of the steps you took while you were at home.

This means that over this time period you were only wearing your boot for {{stepsPerc}}% of the steps you took, which is likely to have contributed to the deterioration of your foot ulcer over this period.
For the best chance of a good recovery, you should wear your boot all the time you are active. This means you need to wear it when you’re at home as well as when you go out.

Comment: This dialogue assumes persona 1 at the end of week 12. Triggered by the researcher (to simulate the system being triggered by what it has seen in the data) the system will initiate the following dialogue.
Print: Hi, {{p1name}} doing really well with {{p1posspronoun}} boot at the moment! Have a look at the information for the last two weeks. You need to XXXXX.
This week {{p1name}} has worn {{p1posspronoun}} boot for {{p1s1stepsPercTotal}}% of all the steps {{p1pronoun}} took!

CondJmp.msg: I’ve think {{p1name}}'s boot has given {{p1pronoun2}} really bad back ache. Is there anything {{p1name}} can do to make {{p1posspronoun}} back hurt less?

Comment: If I can’t talk now, then
Print: Ok, you know where I am if you need me. Bye!

Comment: If I’ve been making myself wear my boot but it’s been giving me really bad back ache, is there anything I can do to make my back hurt less?, then
Print: If you have another boot or shoe that’s a similar height to your boot then you can try wearing that on your healthy foot, this might reduce your back ache.
I’ve sent a message to your healthcare team to let them know that you’re suffering from back ache. They will be able to discuss with you different things you can try to reduce your pain.

It’s really important that you keep wearing your boot. If you take a look at the temperature difference between your ulcer and your healthy foot then you can see that it's decreased by {{degrees2weeks}} degrees over the past 2 weeks.
This is what we want to see, it suggests that your ulcer is improving. If you continue to wear your boot for most of your steps then we can expect your ulcer to keep getting better.
The foot clinic team will discuss your progress with you in more detail the next time you see them. Keep wearing your boot, you're doing great!

Comment: If Great, has my ulcer improved?, then
Print: If you take a look at the temperature difference between your ulcer and your healthy foot then you can see that it's decreased by {{degrees2weeks}} degrees over the past 2 weeks.
This is what we want to see, it suggests that your ulcer is improving. If you continue to wear your boot for most of your steps then we can expect your ulcer to keep getting better.
The foot clinic team will discuss your progress with you in more detail the next time you see them. Keep wearing your boot, you're doing great!

Comment: This dialogue assumes persona 1 at the end of week 12. The researcher triggers the dialogue to simulate that, as per the patient's preferences, every Sunday at 6pm the system will initiate a dialogue with the patient to review their progress.
Print: Hi, how's your week been?

CondJmp.msg: I don't want to talk to you now

Comment: If I don't want to talk to you now, then
Print: Ok, you know where I am if you need me.

Comment: If Great|Ok, then
Print: Glad to hear that!

Comment: If Really awful, then
Print: I'm sorry to hear that, I hope next week is better for you.
How have you been getting on with wearing your boot this week?

CondJmp.msg: Good, I've barely taken it off
I don't think I've worn it as much as I should have done

Comment: If Good, I've barely taken it off, then
Print: That's great! I can see from your data that you're right, you've worn your boot for {{stepsPerc}} % of all steps you've taken this week.
This means you're wearing your boot for more than {{bootTimes}} times as many of your steps than you were 4 weeks ago, which is great. Do you think this has had an impact on your foot ulcer?

CondJmp.msg: Yes, I think my data shows that it's getting better

Comment: This dialogue assumes persona 2 at the end of week 12. Triggered by the researcher (to simulate the system being triggered by what it has seen in the data) the system will initiate the following dialogue.
Print: Hi, did you know that in the past 4 weeks you’ve only worn your boot for {{stepsPerc}}% of all the steps you’ve taken?

CondJmp.msg: That can’t be right, I always put it on when I leave the house
I haven’t been wearing it so much because it’s been giving me really bad back ache.

Comment: If I can’t talk now, then
Print: Ok, you know where I am if you need me.

Comment: If That can’t be right, I always put it on when I leave the house, then
Print: I can see that you always wear you’re boot when you go out, but actually over the past 4 weeks {{stepsPerc}}% of all the steps you’ve taken have been at home.
Because you’re not wearing your boot very much while you’re at home, in total you’ve only been wearing your boot for {{stepsPerc}}% of the steps you’ve taken over the past 4 weeks.

If you take a look at the temperature difference between your ulcer and your healthy foot then you can see that it's increased by {{degrees}} degrees over the past 4 weeks. This suggests that your foot ulcer has been deteriorating.

You need to wear your boot more often, especially while you're at home. Up until 4 weeks ago you were spending much less time at home, and were wearing your boot much more often. During this period your foot ulcer seemed to be improving --- the temperature difference with your healthy foot dropped by {{degrees}} degrees. If you start to wear your boot more often we can expect to see an improvement again.

I’ve sent the foot clinic team a message to let them know that you haven’t been wearing your boot very much while you’ve been at home and that you’re foot ulcer seems to be getting worse.
